text:
S-X2
265. Kajewski, Mary Edith Alicia (Mrs. H.H.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mary Edith Alicia Rajewski
Address: Box 189, Craik, Sask.
Birthplace: Wallaceton, Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1909
Where did you set up housekeeping? Cypress Hills West
Where had you been living before that? Qu'Appelle Area
For how many people did you prepare meals? Five
How far was it to your nearest store? 26 miles but for quantities went to Medicine Hat 45 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, Beans, Tea, Coffee Beans, Sugar, Dried Fruits, Nuts.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie's and "True Roses"
In what quantities did you buy it? about 10 or 12 bags
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? about $3.25
How much did you use graham flour? very little
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? about 80¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina? Yes
Other? Rolled Oats, cracked wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can, and mail it to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Kajewski, Mary Edith Alicia (Mrs. H.H.)
Address: Box 129, Craik, Sask.
Birthplace: Lwówek, Poland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in western Canada? 1909.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Cypress Hills, Saskatchewan.
Where had you been living before that? Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 2.
How far was it to your nearest store? 24 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, coffee beans, flour, fruit, nuts.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Aigle.
In what quantities did you buy it? About 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $3.25.
How much did you use graham flour? Very little.
Whole wheat flour? Yes.
Was flour milled locally? No.
How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.50.
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal.
Other? Whole Wheat.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.
How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy this sugar? ... in 100 lb. bags ...
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ... $0.50 ...
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...
At what price? ...

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Not always -
When I first went to ranch used canned milk -
Butter? From mother-in-law's eggs? Yes ...
What was the price of butter? ... of eggs? ...
Did you pick eggs for winter? ... Yes ... how? In oats ...
At harvest time paper - stored in cool cellar -
Did you make butter? When we had cheese? ... Yes (dairy)
What kind of cheese? Skim milk (Cottage) Cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, fresh ...
Killed - Pork -
How did you get fresh meat? Killed - shared with neighbors. In summer ducks & geese (wild) -
In winter sometimes deer -
How often did you get fresh meat? ...
How did you preserve meat? ... canned or pickled beef -
Pork. Made head cheese -
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes - something?
That sort among neighbors (not official)
If so what year was it organized? ...
Did you use game? ... Yes ... What kinds? ... above -
Ducks, geese, or deer -
For how long? ...
What part did fish play in the family diet? Hot good supply -
in Elkwater Lake - Dinner, winter -
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... Fresh, pickled in croats -
Kinds? Mostly pike or jackfish ...
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Eaton's 35¢
At what price? 75¢
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Brown
Price? Can't remember
What other beverages were used? Corn
Mention something like "Pattum" (or called Cayota?) Bran syrup browned in oven and crumbled

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? Bought them
If not, where from? Garden
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes Cabbage Carrots Onions
Turnips Beets
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lb. bags 5¢ each
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box
What weight? 24 lbs
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 4¢ 0
By lb. I suppose
What was the price of prunes? ...........
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (aples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
We had apples Apples (evaporated) dried peaches Raisins, currants, apricots.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Mother-in-law did
peas? corn? beans? Saskatoons? V
other foods? Mushrooms
That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? Before I was married
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? About 1920
That year did you first preserve meat by canning? About 1920
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning yes
To what extent? Up to about 100-125 annually according
Did you make your own vinegar? A few times
5. **BEVERAGES**

   - **Tea:** 135¢
   - **Coffee:** 75¢

6. **FOODS**

   - **Meat:** 25¢
   - **Vegetables:** 15¢
   - **Fruits:** 10¢

7. **CALIFORNIA AND SOUTHERN PACIFIC**

   - **Potatoes:** 5¢
   - **Carrots:** 5¢
   - **Beets:** 5¢

8. **PRESERVING**

   - **Preserved Foods:** 10¢
   - **Fruits:** 5¢
   - **Vegetables:** 5¢

9. **TO WHAT EXTENT?**

   - **Up to about half of annual consumption**
   - **Did you make your own preserves?** Yes

10. **OTHER FOODS**

    - **Beans:** 5¢
    - **Other Foods:** 5¢

11. **THAT YEAR DID YOU FIRST PRESERVE FRUIT BY CANNING?**

    - **Before 1899**
    - **After 1920**

12. **THAT YEAR DID YOU FIRST PRESERVE VEGETABLES BY CANNING?**

    - **Before 1899**
    - **After 1920**

13. **DO YOU STILL PRESERVE FOODS BY CANNING OR DRYING?**

    - **Canning**
    - **Drying**

14. **TO WHAT EXTENT?**

    - **Up to about half of annual consumption**
    - **Did you make your own preserves?** Yes
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                  | Year you first remember seeing it in the store | How was it sold? - In bulk, 10 lb, sack, can, etc. | Amt. you usually bought at one time | Price of this amount |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------|---------------------|
| Soda biscuits         | 1890(?)                                       | Wooden boxes - they were called "boxes" but sold for less than |
| Macaroni              | 1900                                          |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Graham flour          | (1885-1915)                                   | We had flour mill - we had graham or whole wheat flour anyway |
| Brown sugar           | At sometime it was "Demarara" sugar - about 1895. Remember eating iron bread or porridge |
| Molasses              |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Table salt            |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Common salt           |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Lily white syrup      |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Toilet soap           |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Baking powder         |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Baking soda           |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Dried peas            |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Dried corn            |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Vinegar               |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Raisins - seeded      |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| - seedless            |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Rice                  |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Currants              |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Store jam - kinds?    |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | | | | |
| Vanilla               | Vanilla was in stores when I first started housekeeping 1909 |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Bakes

Did you make yeast for your own use? .............. Using starter? ..............

Using hops? .......... No .......... Salt rising? No ..............

Did you buy baking powder? Yes .......... Baking soda? Yes .......... Cream of tartar? Yes .......... Did you make your own baking powder?

No except 1/2 soda + 2 cream of tartar were the same thing I understood.

Used to keep part of yeast as starter for next bread baking.
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD | Year you first remember buying it in the store | How was it? | Any you usually took? | Price of this amount |
|------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------|------------------------|---------------------|
| Soda biscuits | 1890 (?) | Borden Butter - Yolks cut into "butter" pieces | Had flour, sugar, salt, cream, etc., one time | Usually 50 cents |
| Macaroni | 1900 | Flour mill, white flour, Graham or whole wheat flour | Remember eating "Pompano" | Usually 25 cents |
| Graham flour | 1905 (?) | At sometime it was "Pompano" | Remember eating corn bread | Usually 25 cents |
| Brown sugar | about 1895 | Melasses | Remember eating corn bread | Usually 25 cents |
| Table salt | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Cinnamon salt | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Lily white syrup | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Toilet soap | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Baking powder | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Baking soda | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Dried peas | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Dried corn | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Vinegar | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Raisins - seeded | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Rice | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Currants | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Store jam - kinds? | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | | | | Usually 25 cents |
| Vanilla - started housekeeping 1907 | | | | Usually 25 cents |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? | Regular yeast or baker's yeast |
---|---|
Did you make yeast for your own use? | No |
Using starter? | No |
Salt rising? | Yes |
Did you buy baking powder? | Yes |
Cream of tartar? | Yes |
Did you make your own baking powder? | No |

Note: except for soda & Cream of Tartar, we used to keep part of year as plant for next bread baking.
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon               | 1875                                   |                              |                                               |
| Canned sardines             |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - give names | Remember Binnan-Haddie in 1901-        |                              |                                               |
| Apples - fresh              | Some barrels were shipped to us in Manitoba from Ontario in 1891. Think. |                              |                                               |
|                             | dried                                  |                              |                                               |
| Lettuce                     | Don't remember ever seeing it in stores till 17 years ago (20) years. |                              |                                               |
| Tomatoes - fresh            |                                        |                              |                                               |
|                             | canned                                 |                              | in 1890-1900 - price about 10¢ can. (3¢ for 25¢) |
| Bananas                     |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Lemons                      |                                        |                              |                                               |
| Oranges                     | These were a treat about once a year - 1895 (?) |                              |                                               |
| Cornflakes                  | Around 1909                            |                              |                                               |
| Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names | Grape-nut Flakes. Orange Flakes (?) |                              |                                               |
| Pearl tapioca               | 1897 (?)                               |                              |                                               |
| Minute tapioca              | 1943 (?)                               |                              |                                               |
| Sago                        | 1890                                   |                              |                                               |
| Dates                       | I think these were in stores when I was a child. |                              | I used to pay 35¢ lb. for walnuts |
| Walnuts                     |                                         |                              |                                               |
| Icing sugar                 |                                         |                              |                                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ........................................... well ...........................................

How far was this water from your home? ........................................... 50 or 100 feet ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................... pail ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

and other disturbing experiences.
11. Please fill in the following table to show the year each food item was introduced.

| Food Item | Earliest Date | Approximate Price at the Time |
|-----------|---------------|-------------------------------|
| Canned Salmon | 1875 | |
| Other canned fish | 1901 | |
| Apples - fresh | 1840 | |
| Apples - dried from 1840 | |
| Lettuce | 1890-1900 | |
| Tomatoes - fresh | 1890-1900 | |
| Bananas | |
| Lemons | |
| Oranges - these were a treat about once a year - 1890-1895? | |
| Cornflakes | |
| Other breakfast cereals - orange flavor? | |
| Pearl tapioca | 1891? |
| Minute tapioca | 1943? |
| Sago | |
| Dates | |
| Walnuts | |
| Icing sugar | |

12. Water Supply

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home? (half, barrel, tank)

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

and other disturbances experienced.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ash

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Sunlight, Febreze

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood

Where did you get your fuel? Locally

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

First wood I used was from big pine logs, pared and split. Later, poplar and coal (in Qu'Appelle).

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Yes

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No

By whom was your first cook stove made? McLarty

What year was it purchased? 1909

Price? about $15

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, tin, enamelware

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) All of them

When did you first see enamel ware? All my life, I think. I know husband's parents bought enamel coffee pot from Poland in 1889. It was still in use a few years ago.

Aluminum? 1919, I think
13. What did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Friendship, Wh. Naple.

14. What fuel did you use in the earliest days? How old?

15. Where did you get your fuel? How old?

16. Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Prior wood I used was from big pine logs, owned and split. Later poplar and oak (in Guizapelle).

17. Methods of cooking and types of utensils

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Yes.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Price of stove?

What year was it purchased? 1909.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homesteading)

For preparing food (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) all of them.

When did you first see enamel ware? Oil range, gas range, electric range.

Aluminum? 1919.

Steel in use a few years ago.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Tea was not packaged. Came in bulk in cases of 20-50 lbs., lead lined. Sometimes in 3 lb. cans (I don't remember what they were called). Biscuits came in barrels in stores. I think soda biscuits came in barrels. There were ginger snaps too. Tea cases, by the way, were marked with Japanese writing on outside. At home we used particularly "Uncolored Japan tea."

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

There was always porridge with milk or cream and sugar. Sometimes molasses. Rolled oats and wheat grits or homestead porridge. Home made bread—plenty of fruit—wild raspberries, strawberries, cranberries (in jelly, jam, or mincemeat). Meat of excellent quality and variety—food game. Good home grown vegetables, canned tomatoes. Good Ontario cheese, homemade cottage cheese. Good butter and cooking always plentiful.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

I think the first one not at our or its other parental home must have been 1912. I cannot remember exactly. There were our three children, Thomas A., Mary Kathleen, and Noah. My father, and mother David and Alicia Moore, my brother Charles Moore—perhaps Kate, Kathleen Bedford and husband, Lester, son Fred Bedford aged 2.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers used with the food you purchased (two dozen where possible).

In our new house, canned goods were stored in 3rd and 4th floor garages until about 1978. Bread was stored in the basement.

Food storage was done in barrels. Glass jars were used for preserves and canned goods.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

We always had porridge with milk or cream and sugar. Sometimes molasses-Rolled oats and sugar on commercial porridge. Home made hot oatmeal, plenty of fruit, wild or purchased strawberries, cranberries, in jelly form (commercially). We also had excellent quality, local variety, canned tomatoes. David had home grown vegetables, always tomatoes, corn, cucumbers, cheese, homemade cottage cheese.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

I think the first one not at one on its own was 1932.

Parental home must have been:

Can't remember exactly - none were over three children, Thomas H. J. Mary Kathleen R. and Harold.

My mother, and mother David and Alina Moore.

My brother, perhaps Walt, Kathleen Redford and husband Louise, Don Fred Redford aged 8.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Porridge was made in an iron, 3-legged pot. Remember because cooking it was a big job.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Except for Bread and Butter, we still rely on homegrown and home prepared foods. Meat bought locally and frozen or canned—also fish.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

While on ranch practically whole year's supply of flour, sugar, meals, coffee, tea, dried fruits, nuts etc., purchased in fall of year.

As for shortages I remember particularly that of Coal oil and many other necessities while at Dauphin when only transport for 100 miles was by horse or ox teams. We have taken out of Coal oil for lamps we have used 'wicks' or even rags in saucers used grease of some sort. Ben's oil goose grease etc. were kept whenever possible for medical uses. Dr. Thomas' Eclectic Oil a handy remedy for colds, frost bites, phlebitis and other distressing experiences.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Porridge was made in an iron tagged pot. (Remember because awaiting supplies)

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

Except for Bread and Butter we still rely on home grown and home prepared foods. Meat bought locally and frozen or canned - also fish.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Lotus on range practically whole year's supply of flour, sugar, meals, coffee, tea, dried fruits, nuts etc., purchased in fall year.

As for shortages I remember particularly that of Coal oil and may only transport while at Dauphin by horse or ox teams. For 100 miles was out of Coal oil for lamps so we have used wicks in every part. Please etc. save book whenever possible.

For medicinal uses "Dr. Thomas' Eclectic Oil" a family remedy for colds and other ailments and often dieting young experienced.
No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
Oxford
